abstract: Google fears that Microsoft could leverage its dominance of the browser market to promote its search business.
snippet: Google fears that Microsoft could leverage its dominance of the browser market to promote its search business.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google’s new browser, Chrome, is named for something it mostly lacks.

headline.main: Search Giant Wants a Share of Browser Market
headline.print_headline:
Serious Potential in Google’s Browser: The Search Giant Wants a Share
Of a Market Dominated by Microsoft

abstract: Google’s minimalist Chrome browser is built for a future that blurs the lines of Web and desktop.
snippet: Google’s minimalist Chrome browser is built for a future that blurs the lines of Web and desktop.
lead_paragraph: Does the world really need another Web browser?

abstract: Russell Fine, co-founder of Opposing Views, a site where experts debate issues, aims to provide an alternative to the glut of opinions on the Web.
snippet: Russell Fine, co-founder of Opposing Views, a site where experts debate issues, aims to provide an alternative to the glut of opinions on the Web.
lead_paragraph: Google a controversial topic and you will be swamped with blogs and message boards filled with readers’ thoughts, some insightful, others biased or not factual. Russell Fine hopes to provide an alternative with Opposing Views, a Web site that went live in July. It presents debates between two experts on either side of controversial issues, along with reader responses.

headline.main: An Alternative to the Glut of Opinions Online

abstract: Google’s new Chrome browser could present benefits–and obstacles–to online advertisers.
snippet: Google’s new Chrome browser could present benefits–and obstacles–to online advertisers.
lead_paragraph: Advertisers said on Tuesday that Google Chrome could potentially provide swaths of data about consumers — but that if its privacy mode  proves popular, it could be a giant roadblock for them.

headline.main: Will Google’s Chrome Help or Hurt Advertisers?

abstract: Toolbars account for 12 percent of the traffic to search engines. But not from Google’s new Chrome browser, which doesn’t allow any toolbars to be added. IAC’s Ask Jeeves, which gets nearly half its traffic from toolbars may be hurt the most.
snippet: Toolbars account for 12 percent of the traffic to search engines. But not from Google’s new Chrome browser, which doesn’t allow any toolbars to be added. IAC’s Ask Jeeves, which gets nearly half its traffic from toolbars may be hurt the most.
lead_paragraph: With its new Chrome Web browser, Google is not being quite as magnanimous to competitors as it lets on.

headline.main: Google’s Chrome Kills the Lucrative Toolbar Business
